design a computer system(on paper) based on intel 80386 processor. in your design you have to interface the following devices and components to the microprocessor system bus in order to have a complete basic computer system : *intel 80386 microprocessor  *buffers 74ls244 an 74ls245 *latches 74ls373 *clock generator 8284 *crystal oscillator 40MHz *bus controller  *memory system : 4*128KB RAM and 8KB EPROM *decoding system :74ls138 and 74ls139 and PLDs *I\O devices : parallel PPI ,and serial 16550 UART *timer 8254 *PIC 8259 *ADMA controller 82258 *digital and discreet components you may required - you have to connect all the pins required for your design ,use component data sheet to show all the pins required for your interface. -choose your memory and I\O address ranges -you can use any application tools to assist you in your interfacing design

Modern multi-core processors theoretically have the ability to perform speculative executions along multiple branches of a program simultaneously with its different cores (up to the number of cores in the processor, of course), so if the primary core's speculation was wrong, the system can switch to the core with the correct speculation while the rest flush their pipelines and start new speculations, minimizing those delays. If they don't already, Intel, AMD, Broadcom, and Qualcomm need to impleent that, especially since there is still a lot of software that only uses one core, and lets the rest idle.

What!?! Speed of light becomes problematic at GHz speed for cm circuit lengths!?! And that is why we use cache!?! NO, NO, NO! RAM uses single transistor cells that is dependent on capacitance of the transistor junctions (Which discharges over time and why DRAM needs to be refreshed which also slows it down). This also means that the read and write are slower. Compared to cache which is SRAM which uses bistable flip-flops consisting of at least 6 transistors (Hence more costly per capacity), there is no slow charging or discharging of capacitors, refreshing cycles etc. which makes it much faster. Notwithstanding the fact that the bus DRAM transfers over is slower and narrower than the internal bus of the CPU also slows it down.

But you will never transmit data with a speed higher than the speed of light.

Overall 7/10 :-) I really think this series can have impact on different age groups, and not only people with tech background or motivation. And that would be great! But I also have some critics, hope a useful feedback:  A. Host is talking far too fast. B. Not all technical facts are correct. Example - The reason for few MB of cache is not the SIZE of the DIE. Is the COST of the SRAM, i.e the cost of CACHE memory. Back in time, when we speak of KB,  again COST was the biggest obstacle and first factor regarding CACHE Size. Manufacturing process changed, so die size could've been scaled, but it was not reasonable to do so. Already having the SRAM cost to the roof, leaves nothing for other expenses in the pursue of bigger Cache size and perf boost. So the barrier was and still is COST of SRAM. 3riichard the new AI techniques work by throwing a lot of computing power at a problem. Branch prediction algorithms have to be simple, otherwise they are too slow.  But! There could be more AI techniques used in compilers.

Very basic AI techniques are actually used in modern branch predictors! Commonly, a CPU will have several different branch predictors that work in different ways and are good in different situations. The CPU can compare these different predictions, and if one is more frequently correct, it will weigh that predictor more heavily when it makes future decisions. Or if one predictor is always wrong, the CPU can figure out to ignore it. Search "perceptron branch predictors".

Unlike CPUs, GPUs work by parallelism. All instructions are being run simultaneously instead of dealing with it individually. However, it can only deal with simple instructions and not instructions that will affect one another. You can think of a GPU as a gifted child that can calculate all simple math addition problems given at once, but cannot do complex university math. CPU on the other hand, can be think of as a university student or grad that can do complex math problems, but cannot do simple math addition all at once.

There are several ways to talk about computer speeds. One is MIPS (millions of instructions per second), but since different instructions might take up different times an alternative is to measure MIPS while running a specific program: the Dhrystone "benchmark" application. This will tell you the D-MIPS number for your computer. But this program tests operations with integer numbers (like 42) while some applications do math with floating point numbers (like 0.0745 or 1.6e45) instead. So an interesting number to know is how many FLoating point OPerations per Seconds (hence FLOPS) your computer can do. If it can do millions then you can say how many Mega FLOPS it can do and if billions then Giga FLOPS.

ya possibly, however you get diminishing returns with each sequential thread.... I wonder if super computers do have hyperthreading? I assume not because they do mass calculations with each core, and hyperthreading takes up space with a mini core in addition to the other core being threaded. It's probably more cost effective to just have more cores than have some space allocated for hyperthreading... but I don't know.

Hyperthreading is Intel's proprietary Simultaneous MultiThreading solution, please refer to it as SMT. Intel cores would have HT and so most supercomputers do have HT, although China's supercomputer is running a custom core created in China and so should have SMT if they want to be efficient about it. SMT creates more heat however because you would have less time between clock cycles. (SMT basically takes advantage of the delays and create a virtual core)
I think it would be more efficient to not have a multi threading. especially if you designing something that might not necessarily use it.

Supercomputers would probably use SMT, because it would be more space-efficent. Then again you do lower your power efficiency and heat efficiency. It's better to include it than to not have it at all, that way you could turn it on when necessary.
there isn't much necessary for it, you only use supper computers in very specific tasks, its not a desktop. I think you would be wasting cores if you started threading them.

how would you waste cores if you started threading them? SMT can double and even octuple the effective cores. Threads are basically cores. Super computers can still benefit as power efficiency (which is very important when you use so many watts already) is increased.

Threading only works if you have underutilized and or idle cores, so while you CAN double and even octuple power for a program not using all cores. I'm wondering if you wouldn't need it on a custom computer like a supper computer ruining custom programs that use ALL cores. It would make more since to me to have more cores running at full potential, rather then have some core space taken up by threads that wouldn't "theoretically" be used to their fullest potential because no cores are likely idle.

Well to start with, there's still a pretty hefty gender gap that is probably holding this particular series back a decent amount. Not to say that this isn't interesting, but Computer Science regularly makes my brain explode, whereas mythology is pretty easy to follow.
Mythology = Easy answers that happen to be mostly false. Computer Science = Real answers that take a lot of processing!

That's like saying: History = real answers that are mostly true; Computer science = real answers that are mostly boring!  Mythologies are easier/more popular because they are retold as stories. They have a narrative and a human connection that's been repeated over millennia. Compared to computer science, which usually is impossible to relate to the human experience, mythology is far easier to digest and enjoy.
Haha, I was just messing around! Thanks for the insight!

I think the real difference is that mythology consists of simple (comparatively) stories, which ,like you mentioned, are easier for most to relate to. Whereas computer science includes a LOT of technical details and may even require a new level of abstraction in thinking (seeing the smaller picture) for those more inclined toward mythology. I enjoy mythology from time to time, especially the Eastern variety.

I'm not surprised.  Mike Rugnetta already has a large audience.  That is going to boost the Mythology views.  And while Carrie Anne is doing a good job, Mike has much more experience at presenting in this format.  Additionally, you can watch each mythology episode individually and casually.  You can just pick up a few random facts, be entertained, and then move on without much issue.  But for CS, you need to watch this sequentially and in detail to really understand what is happening in later episodes.  For people who are just watching youtube for entertainment, that's a lot of work.

Did I say she wasn't good?  No.  I said that she is good.  I've already taken assembly and computer architecture, but it's still entertaining for me to watch her present it.  My point is that she's good, but he's better at presenting on YouTube because he's got a lot of experience doing it.  He's even an example in this article about it: https://www.theatlantic.com/technology/archive/2015/12/the-linguistics-of-youtube-voice/418962/  That is a factor in getting views on YouTube.  It is one of the things that contributes to the difference in view counts between the 2 series.  The thing with the mythology episodes is that you don't even need to know the basics.  If you didn't take in any of the info of one mythology episode, you can generally watch another episode without any issue. Even you feel that it takes knowing some basics already to make it not hard to take the info for the CS series.  So, having "that audience" that knows something already for each episode (which might be dependent on learning some basics from the previous episode) is going to be more limited than when the potential audience is nearly anyone regardless of if they know the basics or not.  So, as far as I can tell, it seems like you are in agreement with me.

I think it's because world mythology is simpler and doesn't require you to have watched all the other videos to understand. I love mythology personally so I'm not dissing it or anything, but I don't have to think hard; they're just fun, entertaining, often weird, relatable stories. Compare this to the CS videos where I often have to go back to several sections and listen again to make sure I understand the concepts properly, so it takes more effort to watch.
